source.title: Fabaceae

source.citation: Modified from: Jeanes, J.A. (1996). Fabaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaflets usually more than 10 mm wide; flowers rather crowded; fruiting pedicels shorter than calyx; sub-shrubby erect plants
Leaflets usually less than 10 mm wide; flowers distant; fruiting pedicels longer than calyx (at least when fruit is mature); prostrate, sometimes twining, to slender ascending plants

Leaflets similar in shape throughout, usually broadly obovate; petiolule of the central leaflet similar length to those of lateral leaflets; pods constricted from both sides between articles; prostrate, mat-forming and/or twining

Leaflets usually strongly dimorphic, the lower ones broadly obovate, upper ones elliptic or narrow-elliptic; petiolule of central leaflet twice as long (or more) than those of lateral leaflets; pods constricted between articles from ventral side only; usually ascending (at least in eastern Victoria)
